data.title: Arch of Hadrian at Athens: a Pleiades place resource
data.meta_description: The Arch of Hadrian is a monument in the form of a Roman triumphal arch, constructed by the citizens of Athens in AD 131 or 132 to honor the Roman emperor Hadrian.
data.meta_site_name: Pleiades: a gazetteer of past places
data.text:
Use this tag in Flickr to mark depictions of this place's site(s):

pleiades:depicts=235795850

or this one to mark objects found here:

pleiades:findspot=235795850

Details:

The Arch of Hadrian was built by the city of Athens to celebrate a visit by the Roman Emperor Hadrian in AD 131 or 132. Its structure is similar to that of a Roman triumphal arch with a single opening, but the attic of the arch is occupied by a series of Corinthian columns supporting a triangular pediment in the center and an entablature on each side.
